Somewhere around seventy five thousand years
ago - don't worry, I'm not going to go too

long on this - but around seventy five thousand
years ago, human beings who were anatomically

and behaviorally the same as us modern human
beings -- a few of them decided to trek on

out of Africa and begin a forty thousand year
project or so of populating virtually the

entire world becoming a global species which
we are now, perhaps the only global species,

with I think the possible exception of cockroaches.
I'm not positive of that but I think that's

correct. And now we find ourselves on the
threshold of becoming possibly a universal

species or at least entertaining ideas of
inhabiting places beyond this earth that we
live on.

So this new migration however, I have to say
is different not only quantitatively from

the original ‘out of Africa’ diaspora
but qualitatively because we're now talking

about a migration to a place that has never
influenced our evolution in any way. And so

the question is, will we be able like the
first migration to be able to do this by the

use of technology and science without really
changing our biology? Or will we now have

to resort to changing our biology to making
ourselves in some way or another more adapted

or more adaptable to environments that are
even difficult to predict?

So let me welcome our panel. To begin with,
our first participant is a geneticist and

associate professor at Weill Cornell Medical
Center. Please welcome Christopher Mason.

Also with us this evening, Professor of Genetics
at Harvard Medical School and the Director

of the Consortium for Space Genetics. Please
welcome Ting Wu.
Good evening, Ting.
Hello.

Our final guest this evening is the Director
of Astrobiology at Columbia University where

he studies among other things the conditions
on other planets that make them habitable
for life.

Please welcome my friend and colleague Caleb
Scharf.
Hello, have a seat.
Thank you.

Good. I'm going to jump right into this with
a question to Caleb, who said in his Scientific

American blog that the possibility of humans
living on other planets is quote, "Terrifyingly

hard to think about and that's the best thing
about it."
What's hard and what's so good about it?

Well I think some of these other people on
stage are going to explain what's hard about

it and what happens when you go to environments
that are radically different than the one

we've evolved out of. But what's good about
conditions on another world or in space being

so horrifically difficult, from my perspective
and what I was getting at when I wrote that

article was the idea that every time humans
are challenged with something radically new

and especially in exploration, especially
in survival, it's the opportunity for good

things to happen. It's the opportunity for
us as a species to expand not just physically

across new territories in our solar system
but as a species our conception of what it

means to be human alters, and our conception
of the preciousness of the origins that we
have here on earth I think expands and improves.

So that was really what I was getting at,
this idea of -- you know there are lots of

motivations for our species to spread itself
into the cosmos. I mean there are motivations

that are quite simple to do with potentially
having a backup plan. Living on a planet is

an inherently treacherous thing, especially
on longer time scales and most of us experience

in our lifetimes. So having a sort of off-world
storage system and off-world backup plan is
not a bad idea.

And of course the scientific enterprise exploring
the universe around us humans are pretty good

at that. I mean we build wonderful robots
to explore the universe around us and that

gets us a long, long way. But there are many
reasons to believe that putting a human in

an alien environment is the single most efficient
way of learning about new places. And I think

the Apollo astronauts were an example of this.
When you put a geologist on the moon, they

did more than a couple of hours than you could
do with a rover in years and years and years.

Chris you think a lot about the future and
long term futures, which I which I find very

intriguing because I think a lot of our science
tends to be, you think of scientific experiments

that you hope you'll see the results of in
your lifetime. So that puts sort of a narrow

vision and one of the wonderful things about
science for me is this kind of wider, bigger

frontier. So you're making plans out for five
hundred years is it? Is that what you're thinking
of?

We're on year five of about a five hundred-year
lab plan.
Is there funding for that?

Not funding for all of it. I will of course
be dead for the vast majority of it. But I

think it's actually really one of my favorite
things. Well first it's terrifying for people

who want to come in the lab they think they're
going to be there for five hundred years.
I know graduate students just like that.

So you know not in the sense to have the experiment
necessarily go that long, but actually to

think about a multi-stage plan to learn as
much as we can about the human genome and

other sort of the ecosystem that we all are
represented by as well as ways to find, sort

of, what I like to call "do not disturb" lists
in places that we can alter to some degree

in the human genome and the other genomes
we have. Because I think we will have to have

this list as sort of, a parts list of the
human genome as some people call, or the areas

that you can tweak because we will probably
need to do it for some of the places that

we'll go. Mars is not a hospitable place.
And so a lot of the plan is to learn as much

as we can in a functional capacity in the
near twenty-thirty years and then begin some

of the engineering and long-term tests of
people on other planets and I think it's a

very quintessential human trait, is that we
all have an innate capacity to actually plan

beyond our own lifetime, which as far as we
know is unique to our species. And so I think

it's our it's your duty as a human being to
at least have one plan that's beyond your

lifetime and the simplest example is just
children. When people have children it's obviously
beyond their lifetimes.
Students.

So one of the places that I think actually
makes a job of planning that is the is the

Consortium for Space Genetics which you direct,
Ting. Could you tell us what you do at the
Consortium for Space Genetics?

Yes. And perhaps the best way to do that is
a little bit of history of how we came together.
Yes please.

So most of us started in the Department of
Genetics without a focus on space. But of

course many of us were inspired by space when
we were young. So what happened is that one

day I went to a conference and I met Adam
Steltzner, who is the person who put Curiosity

on Mars. And we had a chance to talk a little
bit and he agreed to come and talk in our

Department of Genetics because we knew that
eventually the effort to go into space was

going to intersect with genetic information
and genetic technologies. So my department

actually was shocked that he would come and
talk with us. And people were saying, "Why

is he coming to talk to us?" And then it dawned
on everyone, because we are actually moving

together to try and figure out a way to protect
astronauts in space and to think about five
hundred or five thousand years into the future.

And what happened is, that turned into one
of the most exciting and successful symposiums

we had in our department with graduate students
and post-docs leading that. And the faculty

then, following the graduate students and
post-docs, started thinking more creatively

about the work that they were doing in their
labs and how that work might apply to space.

And that is how the Consortium got together,
sort of an excitement brought by a realization.

Can you give us an example or two of how this
alters your thinking about genetics?

It became -- what genetics is moving very
much into, the realm of application and invention

of technologies that didn't exist, and in
fact possibly genomes that did not exist.

So much of the department focuses on disease,
the detection of disease and therefore information

of personal genetics can help astronauts determine
what their predispositions might be if they're

going to go on a long, long trip in space.
We also do a lot of work on understanding

DNA damage and how to repair DNA damage. There's
work on longevity, how to extend lifespan.

And also, I work particularly on protection
against radiation. So those are all the things

that are happening, and the goal in mind is
to protect astronauts on space but also take

what we learn in space to take care of humans
on Earth.

What about zero gravity? What about low gravity,
microgravity? I mean we know it has physiological

effects, we could talk about those -- we will
talk about those when we get to the twins

a little bit later I guess. But is there any
effect of gravity directly on the genome,

on gene regulation, on gene expression, on
any of those sorts of things? Either of you.

I'd say you know very much so. So as soon
as you get into space we see thousands of

genes changing their expression. What we've
seen in analyzing the data from the last couple

of years of this study is that some of these
genes immediately revert back to their normal

state when you return back to Earth. But there
are still hundreds that stay perturbed that

have lost whatever was regulating them, you
know essentially back to the normal state

so we can see this is the short list of the
risk genes, or the space genes that we're

going to keep an eye on for the next -- well,
for every astronaut that goes up probably.

Are these genes that we know what their role
is, their function is? Or are these just -- I

mean this is just looking at, here are the
genes on earth, here are the genes there-

And the ones that change. A lot of them are
stress response genes, DNA damage repair genes,

so there is definitely a physiological and
genetic response to space travel and that

there is a stress response to a larger degree.
But one of the more surprising things we saw

so far is that the telomeres actually got
longer in space and so we often think of our
genome…
Oh! That's good, isn't it?

being fairly, the fountain of youth in space.
You go up to space and technically you're

going closer to the speed of light so you're
a little bit younger than everyone on Earth

and a little bit taller, so you can be younger,
taller, lose weight, and be younger, technically.

I'm going to sign up again. This is going
to be a tough night.

But there's increased radiation, your body
puffs up, there's no shower, and you generally

exchanged all your microbes with everyone
in a small aluminum can basically. So those
are the cons, I guess I'd say.
I see. I'm glad there's no food here.

There are some interesting genetic responses
that we -- we knew we'd see gene expression

changes because those change every time you
eat, every time you sleep there's a circadian

rhythm or even epigenetic changes for how
DNA is packaged. We expected that.

So I was going to ask you actually about circadian
rhythms in space. I mean, it's kind of an
earthbound idea, isn't it?

Yeah. Well every ninety minutes, essentially
you have a new sunrise and there's really

interesting things that we can also see in
the data is when they go to sleep there there's

no up there's no down so they're just kind
of go in a closet and close the door just

so that it's dark to get some semblance of
circadian rhythm. But the other interesting

thing is when you sleep, normally there's
enough currents in the air because we're all

terrestrial beings that you get enough oxygen
flowing by you and the air moves. But in space,

actually you'll end up sleeping in a cloud
of carbon dioxide, so actually we can see

even there when they wake up in the morning,
essentially they've been you know sleeping

in their own basically gas exchange excrement
and then you can see it in the physiological

responses that they're slightly suffocating
during the night. So there's actually a race

to see who can get the best fan action in
the space station to avoid that.
It's that hard to put fans in the space station?

Well they're loud. Some of it's the noise.
But you get used to it after a while.

Caleb you're a physicist, is there a solution,
like maybe we should make more gravity? Are

there ways of producing at least minimal gravity
environments?

Sure. Well you know in a space station spacecraft
you can always do things like spin it up.

So this is something that -- I mean if anyone's
ever seen "2001", you remember famous scenes

where he's jogging around this great ring
that encircles the spacecraft, and the ring

is spinning. That centripetal force can be
used to mimic the acceleration that you feel

here on the earth or some fraction of it,
and I guess I'm not sure it's ever been actually

deployed in space. It gets kind of tricky
though, because unless you build a really

enormous spinning spacecraft hundreds of meters
across, you can certainly spin something smaller

but you have things like the Coriolis effect
to worry about. So if you reach across to

grab something, where your hand is is now
in a different moving frame where the rest

of you is. Or you throw something to your
colleague across the room, it'll kind of go

'wooooo' around a corner. So it introduces
other complexities to living in space. But

my understanding is -- and I don't know if
this is really true because it's not a perfect

mimicry of gravity -- that you can certainly
create a form of artificial gravity by spinning

up the environment and living on the inside
of a spinning ring. And that may help mitigate
some of these physiological changes.

So the space station -- and that's sort of
one thing where there's really virtually zero

gravity. But if you were to be on Mars, you're
not in zero gravity anymore, there's less

gravity than here, but there's gravity. Does
it make a difference -- I mean are we that

finely tuned to a gravitational pull that
that even a small difference makes a difference?

I think -- I don't know if we know, actually.
I mean you know the moon is 1/6 the gravity.

People that were there were only there for
not that long… But the body is quite adaptive,

you can see -- I mean the way we solve it
now on the space station is just with bungee

cords and there's a guy who I met at the human
research program meeting, and you meet people

and he says, "Well I'm the guy who designed
the treadmill in the space station." I was

like, oh that's great, it's really cool to
meet the guy who did that. You know obviously

it's a really cool device but with a limited
market in terms of sales. But it was an amazing

device. And it's a bunch of bungee cords,
a treadmill that's really rigorously designed,

but that is the closest they can get to simulating
gravity. And in the metabolomic data, what's

actually present in the bloodstream, you can
see both the markers for bone density loss

actually the physical loss and calcium shows
up in the urine, as well as all the enzymes

activating for bone deposition, which are
essentially really activated every time you

have something like gravity and so it's an
ongoing battle on the space station for the

astronauts today just to maintain what they
have. But it's hard and I think if you're

on Mars, I think the first generation of people
there would adapt to some degree, I think

the big interesting question would be what
happens in F1, the other second, third, fourth

generations. And that, you know there's been
a lot of science fiction written about how

the people would be taller and misshapen and
look like me in the morning kind of thing,
is what they look like.

So I guess we could get into that a little
bit. I was going to save that for later but

since we're here we might talk about that.
So that would be sort of an epigenetic effect,

right? That by a second or third generation,
you'd begin to see alterations in at least

gene expression if not mutations in genes
themselves as a result of some of these environmental

effects. Is that kind of the idea that we're
talking about there?

So right, we're actually moving into the realm
of Lamarck, where a lineage will pick up a
trait-
I knew he'd come back eventually.

Actually I think Lamarck is coming back, because
this is a proposal that an individual organism,

because of environmental stresses or experiences,
will experience some stress and then its progeny

will actually inherit the response let's say,
that the parent had. And that was looked down

upon for a very long time. However, I can
tell you I was at a meeting recently and finally

someone yelled up from the audience and said,
"Just say the L-word!" And the speaker said,

"OK, I'm talking about Lamarck." And there
is evidence now from many areas to say that

an individual organism may be able to pick
up a response or a trait that will appear

in the progeny in an altered form or slightly
modified form.
And then it will be heritable-

It will be passed on. Right. In some cases
it's heritable for three to four or five generations,

and then the absence of the stimulus will
disappear. In other cases I guess people think
that it can be more permanent.

Even in worms, you know we've seen that multiple
generations -- if you have viruses that will

infect some of the worm C. Elegans -- there's
a model organism, a small nematode. For about

two to three generations they still maintain
some of the defensive microRNAs but then they'll

slowly fade away, so even -- we think of DNA
being heritable, you know epigenetic changes

being heritable but there's even some evidence
that a memory of the RNA responds to a viral

infection is heritable. There's a paper from
Oded Rechavi three years ago that showed this.

And so it's interesting because there definitely
is a cellular memory that is present, what

often we just call "imprinting" but it seems
to be more complex and more pervasive than
originally thought.

I have a question. Am I allowed just a random
question since these two guys are sitting
here?
Sure, why not.
So

Thinking about, let's say going to Mars, people
going to Mars and living on Mars. One of the

things that interests me -- I know nothing
about it but it seems like an important factor

-- apart from the internal microbiome is the
environmental microbiome. Let's assume that

Mars is abiotic at the moment, it's truly
sterile. Then I guess there's two questions.

Should we be bringing along an environmental
microbiome to live in? But if we bring it

from the earth and we dump it on Mars -- which
has less gravity, different radiation environment

-- is it going to go through its own epigenetic
change and not be the thing we want to be

surrounded by? I mean, I know it's very hard
to predict.

Well there's some evidence, we know bacteria
in space become more virulent and have more

resistance to antibiotics. That's been published
by multiple groups. There's even an analogue

even in hospitals, if you look at where the
most antimicrobial resistance markers of the

antibiotic resistance, it's actually present
more on the surfaces than it is of the patients,

from a paper just published two weeks ago,
writ large. The idea being that they're under

such strong selection pressure you might be
enriching for the organisms that might be

the most resistant effectively on these surfaces.
And so it's been one study but it had fifteen

hundred samples, so it's really an intriguing
thought. So to your point, when we send people

anywhere you're sending an ecosystem not just
a person, as well as what their environment

-- and they'll be under a lot more intense
and faster selection pressure as soon as they
get to Mars.

So I think we will have to have you know rapid
diagnostics. You can't send a sample back

to Earth to see what the bacteria is, you'll
have to sequence it there on Mars. And one

of the things we worked on with a team at
NASA was just to do the first DNA sequencing

in space. And so it's now possible to actually
do diagnostics of what it is, so if you had

to pick from one of ten antibiotics, you might
be able to know right away which one to pick
instead of guessing.

Chris, I heard that NASA has a very, very
stringent sterilization process for all the

equipment that actually is one of the difficulties
for designing equipment. And that also, many

years ago a group of individuals or nations
got together to designate certain planets

or certain -- I guess they banned the contamination
of planets. And I think that's being reassessed.
What's the status on that?

The Planetary Protection -- basically it's
an organization within NASA as well as an

agreement between ESA and Jackson, and NASA
is to, as the name sounds you want to protect

other planets from us, vermin, and filth,
us that will go out and distribute our filth.

But really they are obviously for discovery
purposes, they're relatively pristine environments

and you don't want to have discovered alien
life just to have discovered what you brought

with. I actually just had a long email exchange
yesterday with a guy who sequenced the organism

that was cultured from the space station and
he thinks it's alien because it evolved to

be different enough from what's on Earth and
we're debating about whether that's true.

It's a string of bacillus and they're funky
to begin with.

But you know the idea is that we -- I think
it's interesting for two reasons. One is that

it's probably already failed. If you sequenced
the DNA in clean rooms (these are the samples

we're getting in two weeks from now), there's
DNA everywhere. It's really it's literally

impossible to get rid of the most abundant
biomolecule on this planet. You know the DNA

is everywhere if you look at what where it's
coming from, and maybe cellulose is the most

abundant, but in terms of an information-content
molecule, it's everywhere. It's in the air,

it's in the atmosphere, it's deep underground,
it's in hydrothermal vents -- you know there

are bacteria that have had billions of years
of a head start. So they're everywhere. And

we've seen if you take the blank samples from
the cleanroom, they're not actually always

clean. So on the one hand we think maybe we've
already failed or succeeded, depending on
your perspective.

But the other thing is I think eventually,
if you think long, long term, this idea of

planetary protection is fallacious from its
foundation. If you think long enough ahead,

let's say three or four billion years, eventually
the sun will engulf the near planets. And

so let's say we've done a perfect job and
we have wonderful world peace on Earth and

it's Kumbaya every night and there's no famine,
there's no disease, there's no war -- it's

wonderful. But if we're all still here on
Earth, we will all die if we're still here

in three billion years, so again it's a ways
off, but it doesn't matter if you've protected

all the planets, shey will all be engulfed
by the sun. So if you really want to think

about long term preservation of our species
as well as all those of which we're responsible

for, at some point you'll have to go to another
planet and therefore you know lay down the

microbes that were never from there. So the
talk then, to state we live here on this planet

-- we'll have to eventually go to others or
if we don't, it will all go away except for

what we broadcast into space. So I think it's
a nice idea that eventually will have to fail.
That's how I would describe it.

So far, most of what we've talked about is
sort of haphazard in the evolutionary sense

of haphazard. That is, these things will go
out there, they'll survive or they won't survive,

they'll undergo natural selection, maybe some
sort of epigenetic modification if they're

lucky to get through a couple of generations.
But what about the possibility of actually

designing things to go out there, which we
can do now even to our cells with techniques

like CRISPR-Cas9, gene drive. Maybe you could
explain a little bit of that for us and whether

or not this is the kind of thing we should
be thinking about and doing.

I definitely think this is something we should
think about, not just for space applications,

but on the planet. So people have been modifying
genomes for a long, long time. We have quite

a wide variety of ways of doing it but there
are a couple of things that made it not reasonable

to think about modifying in any practical
way and one is the targeting and the others

the efficiency. Those are the two things that
held-
By "targeting", you mean…?

Targeting, you want to modify this part of
a chromosome, you want to just modify that

and you want to do it efficiently. And until
recently, we did not have the machinery, the

enzymatic machinery to do that. And then just
a few years ago, 2013, through this technique,

this mechanism called CRISPR, we now have
the efficiency and much, much better targeting,

as well as two other very good technologies
for modifying genomes: zinc fingers and TALENs.

So this triumvirate of machineries really
give us tremendous potential to modify genomes.

And I think probably many of you have been
involved or read articles, or been involved

in conversations having to do with just how
much do we want to apply this? I would say

it's really almost as if our species has moved
into a new era, we passed a milestone where

we can now intellectually understand ourselves
before even an individual is born, and have

a better understanding -- not perfect understanding.
And now we have the capacity to design. So…

And the responsibility that comes with it,
presumably.

And the responsibility, right. And it brings
up the issue of judgment. We now can think

about genomes and judge them based on all
different kinds of measuring sticks. And this

is what I think the world is thinking very
hard about. We need to involve all different
communities in this.

I'd like to talk about the twins experiment
now, in space -- so back into space a little

bit -- which you were very involved in so
maybe you could tell us a little bit about
Mark and…
Scott Kelly.
Mark and Scott Kelly.

For those not familiar with the study, it
was a plan to -- it was a really unique opportunity

because we had twin brothers, both of whom
are actually astronauts. So could you imagine

being -- I don't know if any in the room are
parents -- but can you imagine being a parent

and being like, "Oh both my sons are astronauts."
People would be at a party and be like, "Yeah

whatever, it's not really true." Like, "No
really, both my sons, my twins sons are both
astronauts."

So there must be a gene for it. I mean clearly
there's an astronaut gene.

We've confirmed that they're twins with the
genome sequence and I can say that for sure
if we had been if we confirmed

They the plan was it was actually launched
at a press conference because Scott Kelly

was going up for the longest American mission
in space which is a full year. And when they

were planning the mission, you can see it
up there, that there as they were planning

out the mission, they said you know, she was
one of the reporters who said well “you

know when on Earth are you guys doing anything
with the twin?” And they said well we don't

know everything in the plan but as soon as
the press conference, so here's a big high

five that the press to ask good questions,
is they said we should do something soon.

Actually the twins themselves really proposed
it to NASA and said we should do something.

So they had an announcement to have people
submit applications and I had actually sent

an application to do astronaut genomes back
and 2010 when I had just started my laboratory.

Actually wrote this really interesting grant,
I said “I don't want any money from you

I just want DNA” and they hadn't yet been
banking DNA from astronauts. Because normally

when you start a lab they give you some funds
to get started, so it was a peculiar grant

but they said “well we don't actually have
anything banked yet”. But then eventually

when I knew they made the announcement, said
so great I’ve got most of it written and

submitted and was one of the labs selected
for. They said okay we have identical twins

and we are going to monitor them everything
we possibly can because the big question was

well “what changes in the body when you're
in space” and I said so “well, no one's

ever looked so we don't know so we should
look at everything we possibly can to understand
the physiological changes to the body.”

So we're looking at the DNA with changes of
genetically, epigenetically that we talked

about, the modifications of DNA. What happens
to your RNA molecules or your transcriptome

as well as the modifications to RNA which
we talked about. Protein changes, metabolites,

how DNA is wrapped in package in all your
cells. Microbes in the stomach and the skin

in the mouth and also in the environment,
but also looking are what are called metabolomics,

are small molecules in your blood. Cognition
how fast actually they can do tasks. We are

also looking at vasculature and doing full
body MRIs and doing all these test. We had
over nineteen time points.

The amazing thing about the study was not
only ,it felt like a Michael Crichton novel,

if you know Michael Crichton's books, where
they get a peculiar mix of scientists like

you a mathematician, and you need a geneticist
I mean a physicist to go to Jurassic park.

It was like a weird mixture of people and
there are too. We have a telomere biologist,

some geneticists some proteomics experts a
guy who spends all day designing computer

games for cognition testing, a cardiologist,
its really it's a team effort and you know

which is one of the team. But it's also forces
to think about systems biology, so you want

to measure all of these changes and then integrate
them, there actually is not really an infrastructure

that exists either for medical records at
hospitals or for astronaut-monitoring to integrate

all that information. So it's been a computational,
exciting challenge, you talked about challenge

before. It's great because it's the most challenging
integration problem that we have.

But then also some of the biology has been
really interesting. We've actually seen already

that you're telomeres get longer in space,
the stress response genes really activate,

the microbiome inside your gut changes, but
that wasn't too surprising, they’re are

also eating different food. And we can also
see you know some of the responses to the

hypoxia you know the changes and whether it
changes in oxygen and

Was the earthbound brother or the same diet
and all the rest of that.

We tried to get Mark to have the same diet
and he politely refused or actually not politely,

he definitively refused and said “you can
go…”, and you can imagine the rest of

that sentence. But we did get them both to
keep food logs and his log though was more

you know…so Scott's up in space is highly
regulated food. It's rehy, rehydrated and

then heated. There's a little bit of exchange
with the Russian side so they do exchange

some food and other odd things we keep track
of, so the Russian water supply is different

from the American and European. The Russians
